body.p:
I was anxious to reply to yours of 16th
immediately on its receit? & to thank you for putting me in conceit
with myself but a variety of domestic arrangements & some family letters
of importance compell'd me to delay replying to your very flattering favor.
Tis very pleasant when out of humor with the world & yourself to break
the seal of a letter (from a kind of friend in a quiet corner of the world)
which excites yourself love & throws a little rose colour on the dark
tints of life. In a constant intercourse with the world I have had
much to mortify & distress me but as yet my sincerity in friendship has
never been doubted & you do me only justice my kind friend, in
judging that I am as jealous, in your cause, as you have found
me in that of newer friends. Think not you are alone in receiving
censure where you expected approbation. Although not a public
character, my motives are often misconstrued & wrong interpre
tations given to them even by some very dear to me, I regret
it but sorrow not, as one without hope; for I know ere a little
while, all that appears dark, in my actions, will be illumed
by the light of truth! The task is a painful one to extract
the sweet from the bitter which the hand of malevolence is too apt
to surround us with, but I should feel prouder of you, my respected
friend, if there was less of the human & more of the humane feeling
in your expression of discontent towards the fair dames of Charleston
remember “To these who suffer much, much shall be given”

For patience wears the brightest wealth in Heaven.”
God has endowed you with so much deeper knowledge than your

fellow, has gifted you with perception so far superior to ours; has inspired
you with power to illumine the path of your benighted people, has
blessed you with the power of elevating the Jewish character so as
to place it (if not superior) on a level with the religionists of other
faith that we marvel when we finding you entering into the
sarcasms of those inferior to you in mental blessings — methin
ks I hear you exclaim “But does Mrs Moise think, because I am
more endowed with intellectual resources, more deeply versed in
a knowledge of God & his perfectibility than those around me I am
exempt from human passions & human weaknesses & by no
means my dear Sir, but that you have the ability to root out
with a stronger hand, the tares that spring up among your wheat
& when we find you wanting where are we to look for examples
to pattern by. Our letters of late have all contained, something
relative to Mr. P, let us by mutual consent, banish him, for
I wish at this distance, to see none of the dark shades thrown
around your portrait & I fear he can never be introduced
without producing frowns, where I desire smiles, I have read the
poems of the Misses Moise some years ago & was much pleased
with them, as they gave much promise of a rich poetic fancy accompani-
ed by the freshness of youth, you are happy in having such contributors
to your labors & I should be most happy to enlist as a subaltern
even in your company, had I the time to devote to literary pursuits
In bygone days I had leisure & would have repaid your patronage
by a promise of future usefulness but alas now I must check
all ambitious aspirations & plodd on in the every day walks of life
satisfied, if I can as an accountable being, act my part in my path in life
amidst its trials & its duties & reconcile myself with the reflect-
ion that the soul is invigorated by the difficulties, & purified

by the trials it meets & overcomes in the journey of life — I have
3 or 4 unfinished communications which have been commen
ced since your Occident but I have not the time nor desire
to appear before the public under your scrutinizing eye.
I have had much lately to distract my mind from gleaning
any of the honors you are ready to bestow on humble aspir
ants in the cause of Israel. A beloved brother who I always
viewed as a pattern of piety who I was proud of for his beauty, his
talents & filial piety has doomed me to despair & his parents
to sorrow by marrying gentile woman; had he in youth
allowed his fancy to get the better of all those lessons inculcated
with a mothers watchfulness I would have pitied & forgiven but
when at the age of 40 when the passions are cooled by reason
when reflection must awaken the decree issued against
all who marry with the heathens how can I excuse him!
He was my favorite brother my pride & glory & how has he
disappointed my fondest hopes; yet if God will forgive him ?
? surely ought & yet I feel it hard to write the word
my son too my first born is about to leave the home of his
fathers & seek his future in New Orleans he will not go
without my consent & I have given it because I know that
when our influence fails opposition will avail naught.
his object is to render his mother's & orphan sisters & broth
ers life more affluent, but I am selfish & would rather
have a scanty pittance surrounded by my children & bring
ing the sunshine of their love than the wealth of indies
I fear that absence may do its work of forgetfulness
& what would life be to me without the certainty of
being beloved & having something to love on earth

you say I am impulsive therefore you must not scrutinize
my letters, for as my thoughts pious so do I pen them & you
must be thankful that my pen cannot fly as swiftly as they
do or what a heterogeneous mass you would be taxed to read
But I have some correspondents, that I have to compose
my letters for, & they are anything but agreeable ones; but to
those whose friendship I can depend on, I throw them
on paper, as they rush to my mind without any regard to
style penmanship or order. I have read several numbers of
the women of Israel & am much pleased with them Miss
A with a happy talent imparts interest & character to many
which in the sacred book are only remarkable as the wives of
good & great men & as being mothers of the Jewish family. We
have bought it for our Library thereby enabling those scholars
who can appreciate them to read them, as well as children of a
larger ? I often sigh, that my means, will not
sanction, my indulgence in possessing, every book that
comes out, relative to our people. I am a great admirer of
Charlotte Elizabeth, but have just finished a little work
(sent to Rosalie by a gentile friend) that savors quite too
much of the Saviour to suit my taste — I shall not allow
her to read it, as I cannot expunge, what is objectionable
which I often do, in works sent to her, there being such as connec
tion as to render it quite unintelligible by so doing — Aprospos
do you know what her real name is? Have you heard that
Miss Henry Myers is married to Tuckerman the ? And
Charlotte to Griswold the authors Intermarriages are bad
enough when the young & thoughtless enter into them, but

when women who are in the paper ripped & yellow leaf of time enter
into such engagements what can they hope for.
The report of Miss H's marriage has only reached me but Mrs H
has received a letter from Charlotte informing her, of her marriage
I have a pretty piece of poetry, called the “Dying Hebrew” if you
will receive it, without the authors name I will forward it
our weather is cool & delightful, the autumnal leaves have not yet
begun to fall & remind us, of our departure from this beautiful
world; and we will have no depressing heat to render our appro-
aching fast, uncomfortable, may you be written
in the book of a happy & prosperous life, is my fervent prayers
and at the intercession of the good, for their fallen & sinful
sisters, avails much I hope you will not be unmindful
of one, who stands much in need of forgiveness for positive
as well as negative sins — My daughter & son both desire their
regards, they have a pleasant circle & enjoy all the benefits
of the best society, although I often ask myself, if my precepts are
sufficiently impressed to prevent their marrying with the stranger
God must watch over them; cut off from their own people
I cannot deprive them of the charms of society — I found my
-self on the 5th side without being aware with this mom
ent how I am taxing your time & patience. Let me soon
hear from you & do inform me if there is more union among
your congregation than in 1840 — Remember me to my Cousins
good fortune seems to some to follow them through life; few
are more deserving, but if we judge only by the prosperity of our
friends of their goodness, what a sorry chance some of us will
have — I cry you mercy & will subscribe my self

body.p:
The books are recd — will write
in relation to them when the money
is collected. Yours &c Thos S Moise
Many thanks in for the Saturday post
it afforded amusement to many
of us & S A says her scrap books
has benefitted materially by it.
